 "The cosmos is also within us. We're made of star stuff. We are a way for the cosmos to know itself."
 
 As I said, if you accept the cosmological models, the first two sentences are nothing more than a very brief summary of where the atoms that make up our bodies (and most other non hydrogen atoms) came from. 
 
 The third sentence is just a cool way to look at it. The atoms in our bodies used to be burning in stars, and now those atoms are inside conscious beings that can observe and study nature... The cosmos can know itself. It's not supernatural, or godlike, it's just a fascinating observation about the evolution of the universe.

 "He died on the tree, for you and for me" It's a popular hymn where I'm from, which is where I got that analogy. I wasn't talking about the symbol, but the actual thing.
 
 The analogy with the fish still doesn't 'stand.' Ocean water itself doesn't contain all the necessary elements to make a fish, and even if it did, the fish didn't evolve from the ocean anyway. 
 
 With the mother-child, no the fetus is in the mother, since you are taking such a literal view of things, and no, the entire cosmos is not inside a human. I think that's what your argument is starting to boil down to, and it's pretty pathetic. It's very clear what is meant... "The cosmos is within us" is explained in the very next sentence, "We are made of star stuff." Like it or not, you are a part of the universe, not much different than a cell in your body or a water molecule in a swimming pool. It's like you are trying to distance a person from the universe, but you can't. No matter how small a part we are, we are still a part, and different parts of a system perform different things for that system. You (the whole you) do very little; your taste buds pick up signals as do other parts, although it is understood what is meant when you tell someone that you taste, or feel something. No, it's not a common way of talking about a system as vast and complex as the universe, in part because people aren't aware of the connection we have to it, and that connection was the very thing being pointed out. 
 
 And no, it's wasn't a perfect analogy since the child grows on its own thanks to outside sources... I still don't think it's a stretch to consider the child as being kind of like a part of a parent, since they do share half their genetic information, but the relationship between humans and the cosmos is much greater, since 100% of the makeup of our bodies comes from it. 
 
 And actually, yeah, your awareness/existence does have an effect on the universe. For one, it's been shown that you can't observe something without disturbing it at the quantum level, and as for your existence and your consciousness, the universe would be a different place without them. Would it be a big difference? I'm sure you'd like to think so, but of course in the grand scheme of things, no, it would be a tiny difference, but you have an effect all the same. So if you are just trying to argue that the entirety of the universe isn't inside a human being, then congrats, you win, although Carl Sagan (and I) never thought otherwise.
